headline: Former Toys 'R' Us CEO on importance of the holiday season
subHeadline: Gerald Storch discusses retailers' needs and expectations.

utterances.speaker: TRISH REGAN, GUEST HOST
utterances.sentences: All right, Black Friday isn't even over, and already retailers are advertising their Cyber Monday deals. Online competition from Amazon has many traditional retailers fighting for survival. How is this season shaping up and are retailers banking on those GOP tax cuts?  We are asking Gerald Storch, CEO of Storch Advisors and former CEO of Toys 'R' Us.  Good to see you. Good to have you here.

utterances.speaker: GERALD STORCH, FORMER CEO, TOYS 'R' US
utterances.sentences: Great to be here.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: Tax cuts, how important are they for corporations, for retail, and for the country?

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: Well, I think they're very important. Anything that puts more hands -- more money in the hands of consumers is great. Anything that puts more money back into companies is fantastic. The U.S. tax rate is among the highest in the world.  And retailers, by the way, don't have a lot of special tax breaks or loopholes or anything, so they tend to pay very high tax rates as a group of companies. So, this would be very helpful.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: So, that's what two investors we were just talking about -- talking with were saying as well. But let me turn now to retail and the Christmas season, holiday season, expectations that sales are going to be up 4 percent. Is this going to be enough for the retail sector, which, frankly, has been under so much pressure?

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: Well, there's no doubt that this is a very transformational period for retailers.   But there are winners and losers within that. So, there are winners in the bricks-and-mortar world, like a T.J. Maxx or a Costco that are doing quite well, because they offer great value even in those times. There are companies who are way ahead of the game in terms of getting the Internet and the bricks-and-mortar combination right. And that ultimately is going to be what wins.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: I think, as you read the stories that have taken place this year and what people say, I think it was sort of oversold that the Internet was destroying the bricks-and-mortar retailer, when 85 percent of sales still take place in physical -- physical storefronts.   And so what you saw today, for example, was quite a bit of resilience on the part of bricks-and-mortar retailers, where there were mobs in these stores. I went to Walmart and to Best Buy last night.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: It's a cool, cool thing, though, right?

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: This is what I do for fun.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, it's what you do for fun. Ah.

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: And they were mobbed. They were mobbed.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: The people love -- there's something about Black Friday, right?

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: There is.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: And Americans love to go out and shop and hunt for deals.

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: We are consumers.

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: That's a big part of our...

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: Mobs. And they were in good moods.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: People were having fun. This is a form of entertainment.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: People love to go shopping.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.   So, overall, I think that's a good point, 85 percent of sales still being at brick-and-mortar stores.

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: The issue is, a lot of the growth, if not all of it, is taking place online.  But even there, not all of that's Amazon. A lot of that is the growth in the Internet arms of the bricks-and-mortar retailers.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: So, how should investors be thinking about Amazon? I mean, Jeff Bezos now worth $100 billion. He's seen $30 billion in his own growth this year. The stock is on a tear. Is it too heady for you? Is it getting to a pop?

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: Look, they have done -- they have done -- they have done amazing job.  But I have been expecting it not to keep going from the second or third year it was there, and I was wrong. So I'm not going to call anything negative about Amazon.

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: I would say, though, that there are opportunities in the best bricks-and-mortar retailers, the best traditional retailers.  I mentioned T.J. Maxx. T.J. Maxx is worth more than the entire department store industry. So, if you offer good value, if you take care of the customer, you provide service, a destination they want to go to...

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: It doesn't matter.

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: And if you're good at the Internet, you can do it.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Gerald, it's good to see you. Thank you for coming.

utterances.speaker: STORCH
utterances.sentences: Great to be here.

utterances.speaker: REGAN
utterances.sentences: All right.   END  Content and Programming Copyright 2017 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2017 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
